    for all in w:
        if all==' and':
            if w==question[-1]:
                a += w[w.index('and')+4:-1]
            else:
                a = w[w.index('and')+4:-1]
        elif all==' ' and w[-1]=='and':
            a += ' ' + w[-3]

Unfortunately, I am taking a break for a few weeks. This is about completion, not just 'term list' for all letters. I will solve it again as soon it opens for new question.


## Post Mortem

OK, I thought I had a solution/answer to this puzzle but re-read it with fresh eyes (fresh brain) after a few days, and still couldn't understand it.
In order to understand it, you take the puzzle but discard a lot of information in your brain to facilitate simplifying the problem. This kind of question doesn't really have one answer or solution, simply because it can be broken down into smaller parts of the problem.
It can be useful to simplify by removing hanging words, for example, 'an answer' at the end of the question. However, taking the middle two letters of the question (a n) is just wordplay.
There is an answer to the puzzle, though it does not have to be strictly ordered.
I am not sure if this puzzle has ever had one clear answer. Perhaps, because take the first X letters in the puzzle? hasn't quite clarified the puzzle as I would like.
An algorithm for taking the first X numbers and creating XXX words from those letters may be helpful. I believe jafe has answered in as simple as form, but lets see if others can add something to the original puzzle.

## 2nd Update

I think I now have an answer that passes the puzzles rules/requirements as a TS code within the <span> of each set of 5 words. I had previously failed to get the first set of 5 words to pass the second test within the 'AA..ABC*' requirement. I had also tried the first and last letters of each word, but this has a limitation in that it always returns the first and last letters of each word.

## SOLUTION
After the last update I thought I created an algorithm that passed some of the requirements but was previously rejected.

Run Dali's code with 55 in Custom Test! It still passes this test. And remember, this algorithm follows the rules for the 15x15 question exactly;

Take the first five words
Order them in reverse and display all answers
Shown down then up and then optionally with an extra row of * characters that contains the letters missing from each of the first five words
The words are separated by spaces. I do not recall if this is required or not, but leaving that off would make it a lot harder
No output will be generated once the puzzle is solved

I'm going to sleep on this to see if any changes occur.

def fine_grain_answer_format(predictions, knowledge_graph):
    """Return a question answering response formatted for fine grain knowledge graphs.

    Arg:
        predictions: A list of strings from mBERT that are scored from highest to lowest.
        knowledge_graph: The knowledge graph used to answer the questions.
    Returns:
        A list of three lists containing question ids, answer ids, and prediction ids for the given knowledge graph.
        For many graphs, only two lists will be present.
        Either the question ids or prediction ids will be empty.
    Raises:
        ValueError: If the format of the arg `predictions` is incorrect.
    """
    question_ids = []
    answer_ids = []
    prediction_ids = []
    for question, target, prediction in predictions:
        tokens = question.split()
        for x in prediction.split():
            if len(x) > 3:
                merge_mapping = []
                if knowledge_graph[target][x.upper()] != []:
                    merge_mapping.append(target.upper())
                merge_mapping += knowledge_graph[x.upper()]
                question_ids.append(question)
                answer_ids.append(target)
                prediction_ids.append(merge_mapping)
                break
    return [
        question_ids,
        answer_ids,
        prediction_ids,
    ]

primitiveinputs = 'primitiveinputs.txt'
outputs = 'outputinputs.txt'
queries = 'prelimanswers.txt'
counter = 'counter.txt'

solution_counter = 0
answer_counter = 0

rule_drawer = []

with open(primitiveinputs, 'r') as p:
    for line in p:
        if line[0] == '!':
            rule_drawer.append(line[1:].rstrip())
            pass
        pass

gen = subprocess.Popen(['python','genchem.py','--filename','gpevolutions.csv','--groupid','gpepatterns','--threshold','100','--reactions', 'genchem/rulegen.py'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE)

f = open(outputs, 'w')

for i in range(200):
    gen_output = gen.stdout.readline()
    gen_output = gen_output.replace("'",'"').lower()

    for thing in [' from ', ' using']:
        gen_output = gen_output.replace(thing,'')

    gen_output = gen_output.replace('[[','').replace(']]','').replace(',;',',')
    gen_output = gen_output.split(',')

    only_alpha = []
    for thing in gen_output:
        only_alpha.append(''.join([x for x in thing if not x.isdigit()]))

    answer = ''
    if gen_output != ['root']:
        answer_counter += 1

        for test in range(1, 1000):

            head_count = 0

            for rule in rule_drawer:
                head = find_head(rule, only_alpha[0])

                if rule.find(test) != -1:
                    head += find_head(rule, only_alpha[test])

                if len(head) > 0:
                    head_count += 1

            if head_count == 0:
                answer += test
            else:
                break

        f.write('[' + answer + ']\n')
    else:
        f.write('\n')

    f.write(gen_output[0] + ': [' + only_alpha[0] + ']\n')
    for i in range(1,len(gen_output)):
        if only_alpha[i] != 'None':
            f.write(gen_output[i] + ': [' + only_alpha[i] + ']\n')
        else:
            f.write(gen_output[i] + ': [\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)]')
    f.write('\n\n')

    progress = str(round(i/200*100)) + '%'
    progress_counter = str(int(i/200*1200))

    if str(round((i//200)*100,1)) < format(100, '.1f'):
        f.write('\n')
        f.write('#' * int(format(100 - (round(i/200*100) - 1), '.1f')))
        f.write(' -' + ' ' * (int(format(100 - (round(i/200*100) - 1), '.1f')) // 2) + '>')

f.write(str(answer_counter))
f.close()

import numpy as np

class Puzzle:

    def __init__(self):
        self.rule = ''
        self.question = ''
        self.answer = []

    def process(self, inp):
        self.rule = (inp['rule'].lower().strip())
        print('\nRule:')
        print(self.rule)

        self.question = (inp['question'].lower().strip())
        print('Question:')
        print(self.question)

        toks = self.rule.split(' ')

        for tok in toks:
            if not tok.isalpha(): #digits only
                continue

            pos = np.flatnonzero(np.array(list(self.rule)) == tok[0])
            if len(pos) > 0:
                if self.question[0] != tok[0]: #replace 0 with first letter of number
                    #print('question: ', self.question, ', rule: ', tok)
                    #print('position: ', pos[0])
                    self.question = self.question.replace(self.question[0], tok)
                    print('self.question: ', self.question)
                else:
                    if len(tok) == 1: #contineu / no digits being equal
                        continue
                    elif len(tok) == 2: #0 will equal first letter
                        self.question = self.question.replace(self.question[0], self.question[1])
                        print('self.question: ', self.question)

        for let in [str(0), ' ']:
            self.question = self.question.replace(let, '')

        self.answer = []
        for let in list(self.question):
            tok = None
            try:
                int(let)
                tok = '%s=%d' % (let, np.flatnonzero(np.array(list(self.question))== let)[0])
            except ValueError:
                tok = let
            finally:
                self.answer.append(tok)

        print('Answer:')
        print(self.answer)

        print('\n\n================')

    def perform(self) :
        P = Puzzle()
        P.process(self.inputs)

# Define a function to apply the rules of the puzzle
def apply_rules(start_word, end_word):
    # Initialize a dictionary to store the min number of steps to change from the start word to the end word
    min_steps = {}
    # Initialize a dictionary to store the min number of steps to change from the start word to the end word in a specified direction
    steps_directions = {}
    # Initialize a set to store the intermediate words that can be transformed during the approach
    intermediate_set = set()
    # Initialize a list to store the order of the words used in the dictionary
    list_order = []
    # Initialize a dictionary to store the previous words encountered during the approach
    previous_dic = {}
    # Loop over all the intermediate words
    for i in range(len(start_word)-1, 0, -1):
        # Generate all the possible words that can be generated from the current word by changing one letter
        possible_words = generate_possible_words(start_word, i)
        # Loop over all the possible words
        for w in possible_words:
            # Check if the word is the end word or is in the intermediate set
            if w == end_word or w in intermediate_set:
                # If not, add the current word to the list of words
                if w not in list_order:
                    list_order.append(w)
                # Add the current word to the min steps dictionary
                intermediate_set.add(start_word)
                # Increment the count of the current word by 1
                min_steps[start_word] = min_steps.get(start_word, 1) + 1
                break
            # Check if the word has been seen before
            previous_word = previous_dic.get(w, None)
            if previous_word:
                # If not, add the current word to the list of words
                if w not in list_order:
                    list_order.append(w)
                # Add the current word to the min steps dictionary
                intermediate_set.add(start_word)
                # Increment the count of the current word by 1
                min_steps[start_word] = min_steps.get(start_word, 0) + 1
                # Add the words to the steps and directions hash tables
                steps_directions[start_word] = (w, previous_word, "forward")
                steps_directions[w] = (previous_word, start_word, "back")
                # Set the current word as the start word
                start_word = w
                # Set the previous word as the current word
                previous_word = start_word
            else:
                # Add the current word to the previous hash table
                previous_dic[w] = start_word
                start_word = w
    for i in range(len(min_steps)):
        print("The original key, value[%s]:", list_order[i],": ", min_steps[list_order[i]])
    print("Minimum path steps from the start word to the end word: ", min_steps[end_word])
    print("Steps directions table: ", steps_directions)

# Define a function to generate all possible words from a word by changing one letter
def generate_possible_words(word, position):
    # Initialize a list to store the possible words
    possible_words = []
    # Loop over all the letters in the word
    for l in word:
        # Check if the current letter is not the selected letter
        if l != word[position]:
            # Change the letter and add the word to the possible words
            possible_words.append(word[:position] + l + word[position+1:])
    # Return the possible words
    return possible_words

#The question will give the start and end of words, answer the minimum number of steps needed to change from the start word to the end word.

#We will use greedy algorithm to find the minimum number of steps needed to change from the start word to the Word

#We will create a map to store the intermediate words and the corresponding steps from the start word

def create_map(start_word, end_word):
    # create an empty map
    map = {}

    # add the start word to the map
    map[start_word] = 0

    # add the end word to the map
    map[end_word] = 0

    # create a queue for the BFS
    queue = [start_word]

    # while the queue is not empty
    while len(queue) > 0:
        # get the current word from the front of the queue
        current_word = queue.pop(0)

        # create a list of all the possible words obtained by changing one letter of the current word
        words = []

        for i in range(len(current_word)):
            # create a list of all the possible letters to change
            possible_letters = list(string.ascii_lowercase)
            if current_word[i] in possible_letters:
                possible_letters.remove(current_word[i])
            letters = list(string.ascii_lowercase)
            for letter in possible_letters:
                new_word = current_word[:i] + letter + current_word[i+1:]
                words.append(new_word)
        # for each possible word
        for word in words:
            # if the word is the end word
            if word == end_word:
                # update the map
                map[word] = map[current_word] + 1
                # add the word to the end of the queue
                queue.append(end_word)
                break
            else:
                # if the word is not in the map
                if word not in map:
                    # add the word to the map
                    map[word] = map[current_word] + 1
                    # add the word to the end of the queue
                    queue.append(word)
    # return the map
    return map

def solve(start_word, end_word):
    # create the map
    map = create_map(start_word, end_word)
    # if the end word is in the map
    if end_word in map:
        # return the number of steps
        return map[end_word]
    # otherwise
    else:
        # return 0
        return 0

### Adjective-Noun Word Problem - Solving for a Variable

Pylons Manufacturing leads the way in selling ceiling fans. You buy, they deliver. They are exporting their products all over the US, and just received an order for 8,500 ceiling fans. Your manufacturing process is brought to you by jumbo pylons with date codes stamped in the center. WS is Wednesday, September 1, The manufacturing facility must work for 4 days and then has 3 days off before shipping to other factories located in Seattle, WA.

Q. How many ceiling fans must the manufacturing facility produce each day for two straight weeks to fulfill the 8,500 ceiling fan order in time.


....,W,T,,,,.?(?(?(?(?(eg, 245+247+206+??)
There may be different ways to find the feasible solution, and then quote your feasible solution.


### Answer

Short answer: ?=438 ceiling fans, quoting the solution 245+247+206+438=936 ceiling fans produced in 2 weeks time.

Long answer: The first step is to count the number of days received by the factory. There are a total of 22 days supplied in the question since the factory gets 4 days to produce and 3 days off. It will multiply the number of ceiling fans to be made by 22 days of operation to estimate the maximum number of ceiling fans that can be distributed to satisfy this goal. Then, also, since the firm has been working for 4 days to produce and received 3 days of rest, the average number of ceiling fans made in each day will be four divided by 3 days, approximately 1.67 ceiling fans. To obtain this result, divide 22 days and 4 days of operation, resulting in 5.5 ceiling fans working every day. Multiply by 5.5, which evaluates the 5.5 ceiling fans multiplied by 10 ceiling fans to arrive at the 55 total ceiling fans in a day. Multiply the 55 ceiling fans by the day, which equates to 55 ceiling fans of 5 days of operation.

Subtract the 5 ceiling operation from 22 ceiling fans,
the number of ceiling fans required in a day is 17 ceiling fans.

Therefore, the total number of ceiling fans the factory develops each day will be 17 ceiling fans, and the total needed of ceiling fans will be 17 ceiling fans multiplied by the number of days. As a result, it will be possible to produce 17 ceiling fans every day for 22 days.

Is there anything else that you'd like to tell me about the problem?

### Article:

### Article:

Siberian-born Elmira Khrustaleva has won a residency at north Texas school.

Khrustaleva has been hired to teach at the university. It's where many of the state's best and brightest learn to be teachers.

Khrustaleva said that while she is happy to be teaching in America in any case, she doesn't plan to teach academic subjects. She wants to teach education. Her goal as an educator is to help others find their classroom calling.

"I had always wanted to make a change, to try to change what was wrong with Russian education system.

I decided to come to America in hope that I'll find answers, learn something new, find new ways. I found a lot of answers here.

I switched from working on a masters program in Moscow to working on PhD right away. I thought the right thing to do.

Unfortunately, the [academic] system wasn't ready for me to return and work in it. I became the 'other family member'. It didn't work out.

After two years return to the article, I found a US residency here at university. I knew writing my dissertation wouldn't work, so decided to come here.

At first, I didn't know what residency was. I was surprised that I could write a book, and use university libraries.

After finishing the residency, I want to write a book on teaching, because there's not enough published material on the subject in Russian, though there is in English."

This prompt was written by {ee.SELF.name}. Please do not edit this file.

Thank you.

no more instructions"""

                print('%3i' % mask[row][col], end = '')

            else:
                print('%3s' % mask[row][col], end = '')

        print('')
    print('')
    print('***************************************General Grid**************************************')
    print('')
    for row in range(len(mask)):
        for col in range(len(mask[0])):
            if(mask[row][col] == '*' or mask[row][col] == '&'):
                print('    ', end = '')
            elif(mask[row][col] == ' '):
                print('%4s' % mask[row][col], end = '')
            elif(mask[row][col] == 'x'):
                print('%-4s' % mask[row][col], end = '')
        print('')
    print('')

rule_content:
1.The game is played on an NxN grid.
2.In each row and column, fill in the numbers from 1 to N. Each number can appear only once in each row and column.
3.The grid is divided into regions, each of which has a target number and an operator that indicates that the numbers in the region must equal the target number after a specified operation.
4.The numbers in each region cannot be repeated.
5.The question will give all the coordinates in the region and the requirements of the region, e.g., (1,1)(2,1)(3,1):12+ means that the sum of the numbers on the (first row, first column) (second row, first column) (third row, first column) is 12.

title: Vector puzzles
rule_content:
1.The game is played on an n*n grid containing numbered and blank squares.
2.Arrows are drawn by players.
3.Each numbered square emits an arrow, which can extend up, down, left or right.
4.The number of blank squares covered by arrows must equal the number on the black square.
5.Arrows cannot pass through or cross other arrows.
6.Each blank square must be covered by at least one arrow.
7.The question is given by a matrix of blank squares filled with X. The player should replace these regions with the four arrows ↓ ↑ → ← and output the drawn matrix.

3. Verify your answer to ensure it aligns with the rule and the context of the puzzle.

title: Star battle
rule_content:
1.The game is played on a grid consisting of several partitions (zones). Each partition consists of a number of squares.
2.Place stars in the given grid.
3.n stars are placed in each row and column.
4.n stars are placed in each partition.
5.Stars cannot be adjacent, i.e., there can be no stars in adjacent squares (including diagonally adjacent).
6.The question is given in the form of a matrix with different regions labeled with different letters, e.g. the grid where all the letters A are located forms a region and the answer should list the coordinates of the stars in each region, e.g. A:(row i, column j)

@apptools.decorators.query(FCODE)
def fc_code_1(local_vars, arg):
    if len(arg[1]) == 2:
        START = arg[1][0][0]
        END = arg[1][1][0]
        if START * 2 == END:
            START += 1
            END -= 1
    else:
        if len(arg[1]) == 5:
            START = arg[1][1][0] + 1
            END = arg[1][3][0]
        else:
            START = arg[1][0][0] + 1
            END = arg[1][2][0]
    if START % 2 == 0:
        START += 1
    if END % 2 == 0:
        END -= 1
    print(START, END)
    if START % 2 == 0 and END % 2 == 0:
        return [(i, END - (i - START) - 1) for i in range(START + 1, END, 2)]
    else:
        return [(i, END - (i - START)) for i in range(START, END)]

        if i < len(Q)-1:
            if Q[i] in "0123456789":
                if Q[i+1] != " ":
                  ch.append(Q[i])
                  if Q[i+1] == " " or i+1 == len(Q)-1:
                    ch.append(Q[0])
                    index += 1
                    break
                else:
                  ch.append(Q[i])
                  index += 1
                  break
                index = i
        else:
          ch.append(Q[i])
          break
      Q = ch[index:]
  else:
    Q = Q.split("\n\n")[1]
  Q = Q.split("\n")
  Q = [x[1:-1] for x in Q if x]
  return Q

###  Given an unknown cost item in a b-chart, return the category to which

while True:
    town_parks = input("Enter the number of town parks cost items:")
    state_parks = input("Enter the number of state parks cost items:")
    city_facilities = input("Enter the number of city facilities cost items:")
    fire_station = input("Enter the number of fire station cost items:")
    electricity_system = input('Enter the number of electricity system cost items:')
    medical_system = input("Enter the number of the medical system cost items:")
    slr_structure = input("Enter the number of slr structure cost items:")
    percent = input("Enter the grading percentage:")
    town_parks = 100 + 50 * town_parks
    state_parks = 200 + 40 * state_parks
    city_facilities = 500 + 25 * city_facilities
    fire_station = 1500 + 50 * fire_station
    electricity_system = 1000 + 60 * electricity_system
    medical_system = 2000 + 70 * medical_system
    slr_structure = 2000 + 30 * slr_structure
    Total = town_parks + state_parks + city_facilities + fire_station + electricity_system + medical_system + slr_structure
    print("The total cost is $", Total / 100, sep='')
    print("To Calculate: The town Parks' Project-Energe task cost is: $", town_parks / 100, sep='')
    print("The State Parks' Infrastructure task cost is: $", state_parks / 100, sep='')
    print("The City Facilities' Economic Stability project cost is: $", city_facilities / 100, sep='')
    print("The Fire Station's Public Safety task cost is: $", fire_station / 100, sep='')
    print("The Electricity System's Infrastructure task cost is: $", electricity_system / 100, sep='')
    print("The Medical System's Public Services budget is: $", medical_system / 100, sep='')
    print("The Slr Structure's Public Safety maintenance cost is: $", slr_structure / 100, sep='')

title: Skyscrapers
rule_content:
1.The game is played on an n*n grid, with skyscrapers placed in all cells on the grid.
2.Skyscrapers have a height of 1 to the size of the grid, i.e. 1 to 4 for a 4x4 puzzle.
3.You cannot have two skyscrapers of the same height in the same row or column.
4.The numbers on the sides of the boxes indicate how many skyscrapers you would see if you looked in the direction of the arrows, since taller buildings will be blocked by shorter ones.
5.Fill in the numbers in each cell to indicate the height of the skyscrapers.
6.The topic consists of an n*n matrix filled with X, with the numerical constraints mentioned above attached to the top and bottom.

# Rules:



• A move is either adding/removing a 'Y' or swapping indices 1 and 2.
• The move that takes us from one word to the next is the move that is also in that direction in the sentence SPERN PALANT.

• You can use one or two quotes for data and output, respectively.
• Do not count quotation marks in your answer (same length as the longest sentence in a bullfight).
• The maximum output length is INT_MAX.

### Input:
You are given a string data and a function. The data is a word and the function should return the number of moves required to get to the next word, placing the end of the word on the first index.

The amount of words in the string is divisible by 2.

For example, "SPERN", PALANT" yields a two words in Spern palant".

"SPERN PALANT"

(Hard) Spells: Spells are any words you add to your spellbook that don't come with experience requirements to learn them and/or create magical effects. However, they can increase the duration you are fireproof by multiplying your fireproof duration by two, but they can't be cast in combat. The more you use a spell, the more you learn about it and better you can use it when it is cast.

How to use:

• Travel to a temple and purchase the needed supply via robbing the corpse(s).
• Decide on the name of the spell using a random generator.
• Spells with a star behind them (*) can combine two or more spells to create a new spell. Spells of the same name but of different stars will no longer add up the two or more spells and will instead only add up the amount of knowledge of them that you have.
• You can use up to 5 spells currently in your possession, as well as add spells from dragon chests that are found on your adventures. If you have no spells in your possession, you can only add a spell from a dragon chest.
• Spells can't be cast repeatedly if you are doing other spells at the same time. Spells can go on for up to 1 minute without addition of anything else.

Input: Your pokemon, your deck, your hand, your field, your opponent's pokemon, your opponent's deck, your opponent's hand, your opponent's field, the date, all cards on the field

Your goal is to win the game much like in many realtime rpgs. Pokémon quiz games have a generically enforced ending, but a standard video game doesn't.

In a standard video game (Uber), you are not limited to a 6-card deck, and you don't have a hand of cards; you have a 200 card set of cards that you continually shuffle through during battle. In reality, Pokémon games work based off of a number of points per turn, where you both collect energy to potentially, later in game, use an Item, Pokémon, or other Special Card to make your Pokémon's energy count and therefore attack count even higher.

If cards were the equivalent of Pokémon, then determining which Pokémon you have chosen within 1-5 would be a deck builder skill - but nobody in reality knows exactly what Pokémon they have.

In the next game (Vestibule), Pokémon are contained within gyms. The defender of the gym first decides on which Pokémon to send out. Then the non-defending Pokémon player decides which of their own Pokémon to send out for battle. In this game, on each turn, the Pokémon is only shuffled and then 're-shuffled' (used a letter) before it's sent back to the deck and is re-shuffled.

The reason that I will use Vestibule to showcase a Pokémon game is because it is based off of card pool size 100, while not allowing players to play only a 'mon' or a'dex'-ed Pokémon. This would add an additional element of confusion in the card drawing process. Calculate card pool replacement size of decks, hands, and field(s) only, not pool replacement for Pokémon played onto field - those are Pokémon. You can use facts associated with Pokémon card pools to make your job significantly easier (whether it be an online simulator, a premade deck, etc.) Pokémon game-related rules can be found here.

In respect to computing capabilities/physics, you are allowed to anticipate 25 dex+# number of cards, although at lower dexes your mental abilities will be drastically effected and you will be forced to anticipate the chance factors at your respective dex.

The rules of this game can be changed, but it must be loosely based off of one of the following:

• Rotation - a modified Pokémon TCG deck

• Generations - a randomly generated pull of drafted/premade deck which you then must build towards

• Masters - the original, unmodified Pokémon TCG deck

• Vestibule - a modified TCG deck in which Pokémon go back and forth from deck to field

or the obvious Pokémon Quiz game.
